awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Joel Harris and his research group at the University of Utah are developing a new microscopy technique to investigate the mechanisms of reactions involving biological molecules employed in therapeutic applications and clinical diagnostics.  The measurements are carried out on surfaces that mimic the structure of cell membranes, so that the response can be related to the action of these molecules in biologically- and clinically-relevant systems.  In most investigations of this type, emission of light from a dye label is used to monitor the reactions of the biological molecules of interest.  In some instances the dye label can interfere with the interactions of interest.  The approach being developed by the Harris group avoids the need for the label, and therefore the associated complications.  The fundamental information derived from these investigations should advance understanding and development of new biologically-derived pharmaceuticals (biologics) and more selective clinical diagnostic assays. The group is also extending the tools to studies related to cultural heritage science, and communicating the science to a broad audience through outreach to a local fine arts museum.  The program is training graduate students, undergraduates, and postdoctoral associates in microscopy and bioanalytical chemistry, topics that are relevant to advancing U.S. science and technology.  Additional science education and outreach comes through development of Chemistry-under-the-Microscope exercises in undergraduate chemistry labs.

The measurement innovation in this project is the application of confocal-Raman microscopy to measure biorecognition reactions within individual porous particles modified with lipid bilayers.  Raman spectroscopy is a label-free method that can report the structure and interactions of proteins. A major limitation of Raman is the low sensitivity resulting from small scattering cross sections.  In this work, this limitation is overcome by enhancing the surface area that can be interrogated within a small detection volume through use of porous silica particle supports. The internal surfaces of these particles are modified with lipid bilayers and used as substrates for investigating biorecognition reactions relevant to protein-lipid interactions and bioassay applications. With calibration using internal standards, confocal Raman microscopy can provide both structural information and assessment of absolute surface coverages for biomolecules involved in interfacial reactions.  This research is generating new understanding of biomolecule association, stoichiometry, and structure that govern peptide-lipid membrane interactions and protein biorecognition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research program has developed new microscopy methods to investigate reactions of biological molecules including DNA and proteins.  The chemical reaction between complementary strands of DNA is the fundamental step in duplication and transcription of genetic information in living organisms.  Small molecules and proteins can be used to target specific DNA sequences as biosensors or to control protein expression. Reactions of antibody proteins with their target antigens is the basis of the immune response to infections and has recently been harnessed for new therapeutic applications. The goal of this project, therefore, was to develop new methods to investigate these reactions by immobilizing one of the binding partners on a surface and then reacting it with target molecules in solution. One means of detecting a reaction between an immobilized biomolecule with its target is to attach a fluorescent label to the target and observe a signal from the label when the target reacts.  Early in this project, we determined that the presence of a fluorescence label can a significant impact on the reactivity of the biomolecule and can lead to errors in quantifying the biorecognition process.

To avoid the influence of labels in these applications, we have developed a label-free method of detecting biorecognition reactions using Raman scattering spectroscopy. In Raman scattering, incident laser radiation is scattered by molecules at longer wavelengths whose frequencies carry information about the vibrations of molecules in the laser beam. A major impediment to using Raman scattering for detecting biomolecules is their small scattering cross sections. In this project, the sensitivity limitations of Raman scattering for these application were overcome by a more than 1,000-fold enhancement of the surface-area that can be interrogated within a small detection volume focused into the center of individual porous-silica support particles. The internal surfaces of these porous particles were modified with supported-lipid bilayers and used as substrates for investigating biorecognition reactions and bioassays. Single-stranded DNA molecules were immobilized on porous silica surfaces to study their reactions with complementary DNA strands, small-molecule drugs, and target proteins in solution.

This Raman microscopy technique has generated new fundamental understanding in several areas: antibody-antigen recognition at supported lipid bilayers whose structure mimics cell membranes, the interactions of signaling peptides with lipid bilayers when they target membrane-bound receptors, and the association of a therapeutic peptide with the natural lipids found in the membrane of the eye.  Raman microscopy also provided label-free, quantitative, and structurally informative means of detecting reactions of DNA at porous silica surfaces.  Characterization of DNA immobilized at solid surfaces has been a challenge because previous surface-sensitive techniques are unable to provide quantitative information about base content, length, or structure of DNA sequences. We applied Raman microscopy to characterize DNA duplex (double helix) formation within porous silica particles. Changes in the Raman spectra were consistent with Watson-Crick base pairing.  A double helix formed with a DNA strand having single-nucleotide polymorphism (a single error in the DNA sequence) could be distinguished from a fully complementary strand. The Raman microscopy methodology also provided a convenient and sensitive means of screening the affinity and selectivity of small-molecule therapeutic drug candidates that bind to specific sequences of DNA. The Raman spectra carry information on the specific nucleic acid bases that interact with the drug candidate.

DNA sequences can also be produced that have selective interactions with target biomolecules and are used in biosensing applications.  These DNA aptamers form secondary structures that exhibit strong association with their binding partners. Binding of its target by an aptamer is often accompanied with conformational changes, but methods to characterize the structure and conformations of immobilized aptamers that govern their response have been lacking. The Raman microscopy technique developed by this program produced new fundamental information on how the binding of a target protein changes the conformations of the immobilized aptamer.

The development of the microscopy instrumentation for investigating biomolecule interactions has supported several collaborations, including DNA aptamer development and discovery, assessment of the lifetime of therapeutic peptides in membranes, and studies of electron-transfer reactions at electrode interfaces. The program also trained graduate students, undergraduates, and postdoctoral associates in microscopy and bioanalytical chemistry, topics that are relevant to advancing U.S. science and technology.  The project supported undergraduate teaching in chemistry, along with education and outreach efforts were designed to attract new students into the sciences.
